snippet.textDisplay:
What if, in the end our lives are the same metaphor? If our spirit is the Wind Fish, the Koholint Island is the world we all know, and Marin represents all we loved, everything we put passion on our lives? And when we depart, when the Wind Fish awakens, Koholint Island is no more, but Marin stills there. Marin is real. As everything we make with love and passion.
When the Wind Fish awakens, we'll be lost again, over a plank. Nobody knows. But the seagull will still fly in circles.

Rest in Peace Mr. Iwata. Your departure and this theme made me think. Videogames are a true form of art.
snippet.textOriginal:
What if, in the end our lives are the same metaphor? If our spirit is the Wind Fish, the Koholint Island is the world we all know, and Marin represents all we loved, everything we put passion on our lives? And when we depart, when the Wind Fish awakens, Koholint Island is no more, but Marin stills there. Marin is real. As everything we make with love and passion.
When the Wind Fish awakens, we'll be lost again, over a plank. Nobody knows. But the seagull will still fly in circles.

Rest in Peace Mr. Iwata. Your departure and this theme made me think. Videogames are a true form of art.

snippet.textDisplay: Everybody who takes videogames seriously has that one game that they played as a kid that made them realize that the medium is something special, and not just a toy or time waster.  For me I think it was Link's Awakening.  That ending just blew me away as a kid, as did the rest of the game.

snippet.textDisplay:
Definitely a masterpiece, indeed.

It also has one of the simplest and nicest metaphors I've seen about "playing a video game": to wake the Wind Fish means to finish the game, which means (for both the character and player) to wake up from the fantasy world and go back to reality.

This metaphor is also the meaning of the engraving in the cavern: basically, if you like this virutal world and choose to go on "living" in it, you will eventually (and paradoxically) put an end to it.
snippet.textOriginal:
Definitely a masterpiece, indeed.

It also has one of the simplest and nicest metaphors I've seen about "playing a video game": to wake the Wind Fish means to finish the game, which means (for both the character and player) to wake up from the fantasy world and go back to reality.

This metaphor is also the meaning of the engraving in the cavern: basically, if you like this virutal world and choose to go on "living" in it, you will eventually (and paradoxically) put an end to it.

snippet.textDisplay: This is the only Zelda game where I genuinely cared about the story. Don't get me wrong, I love the great majority of them. Ocarina of Time is fantastic, Majora's Mask might be one of the most amazingly depressing games I've played (and this coming from someone who's played most Silent Hill games), and Wind Waker is just so goddamn charming, but Link's Awakening actually has a story that hits you really hard. It's the Matrix blue pill/red pill dilemma stretched out to a whole game.
snippet.textOriginal: This is the only Zelda game where I genuinely cared about the story. Don't get me wrong, I love the great majority of them. Ocarina of Time is fantastic, Majora's Mask might be one of the most amazingly depressing games I've played (and this coming from someone who's played most Silent Hill games), and Wind Waker is just so goddamn charming, but Link's Awakening actually has a story that hits you really hard. It's the Matrix blue pill/red pill dilemma stretched out to a whole game.

snippet.textDisplay: I love this game too.  When i played it over the summer, i was not sure what i was in for.  My word, this game is an absolute gem.  Among the best GB games i have ever played.  The dungeons are unique and the music is incredible for the time.  It is also one of the richest soundtracks i have ever heard as well.  Everything about this game is just golden.  I truely agree with the fact that it is a masterpiece.

snippet.textDisplay: I love this game... one of the most emotional Zelda tales.
snippet.textOriginal: I love this game... one of the most emotional Zelda tales.

snippet.textDisplay: The game that took some inspiration from the TV show Twin Peaks also introduced a lot of new elements now popular to the series: trading sequence sidequests, the ocarina, setting different items to the buttons of your choice, fishing, etc. To me, Link's Awakening is a masterpiece!
snippet.textOriginal: The game that took some inspiration from the TV show Twin Peaks also introduced a lot of new elements now popular to the series: trading sequence sidequests, the ocarina, setting different items to the buttons of your choice, fishing, etc. To me, Link's Awakening is a masterpiece!

snippet.textDisplay: Beating the boss of Face Shrine (named Façade, which turns out to be a very appropriate name) and then learning that Koholint Island is actually just a dream world created by the sleeping Wind Fish was very memorable. Your mission which is to wake up the Wind Fish suddenly becomes very troublesome and when you finally do it in the end, you can't help but get a bittersweet feeling.
snippet.textOriginal: Beating the boss of Face Shrine (named Façade, which turns out to be a very appropriate name) and then learning that Koholint Island is actually just a dream world created by the sleeping Wind Fish was very memorable. Your mission which is to wake up the Wind Fish suddenly becomes very troublesome and when you finally do it in the end, you can't help but get a bittersweet feeling.

snippet.textDisplay: This game is timeless, it aged perfectly well. The fact that it's set outside the kingdom of Hyrule is very refreshing and gives it a very unique atmosphere. It has my favorite overworld in the series as it feels very dense with things to do and discover, there's barely any space wasted. The dungeons are also my favorites in a 2D Zelda.
snippet.textOriginal: This game is timeless, it aged perfectly well. The fact that it's set outside the kingdom of Hyrule is very refreshing and gives it a very unique atmosphere. It has my favorite overworld in the series as it feels very dense with things to do and discover, there's barely any space wasted. The dungeons are also my favorites in a 2D Zelda.
